payload.text: create a modern, 2026‑ready reimagining of the classic NFL Head Coach game. Focus on deep strategic simulation, immersive UI, and a clean, data‑driven coaching workflow. Build a full experience that blends Football Manager‑style depth, Madden‑level presentation, and modern analytics tools. 1. Core Identity Design a game where the user is the Head Coach + GM, responsible for: Roster construction Playbook creation and customization Weekly gameplanning Practice scheduling and player development Draft strategy, scouting, and combine evaluation Free agency, trades, and contract negotiations Staff hiring, firing, and progression In‑game playcalling and adjustments (no joystick control) The user influences outcomes through preparation, strategy, and decision‑making — not button‑press gameplay. 2. Modern Systems to Include A. Analytics & AI Tools Real‑time win probability Fourth‑down decision models Player fatigue and load‑management dashboards Scheme‑fit grading AI‑generated opponent scouting reports Player development trees based on archetypes B. Franchise Management 30‑year coaching career Dynamic league with injuries, retirements, draft classes, and coaching carousel Owner expectations, budgets, and culture systems Staff skill trees (OC, DC, STC, scouts, trainers) C. Gameplanning Loop Weekly install meetings Practice scripts Situational prep (red zone, 2‑minute, blitz pickup) Film breakdown UI Opponent tendencies dashboard D. In‑Game Coaching Call plays, adjust tempo, manage clock Make halftime adjustments Track player morale, confidence, and momentum Watch the game unfold via broadcast or tactical view 3. UI/UX Direction Design a modern interface inspired by: ESPN / NFL Next Gen Stats Clean dashboard layouts Modular cards and panels Dark mode + team‑color accents Real‑time data visualizations Drag‑and‑drop playbook builder Interactive draft board with scouting layers Prioritize clarity, speed, and a “front‑office war room” aesthetic. 4. Presentation Layer Modern commentary and cutscenes Press conferences with branching dialogue Draft day broadcast package Locker room speeches Cinematic but efficient storytelling 5. Output Requirements Generate: A full feature list UI screens and layout concepts Core gameplay loop diagram Player progression system Draft/scouting pipeline In‑game coaching interface Franchise mode structure Monetization model (if applicable) Art direction and branding Optional: cross‑platform UX (console, PC, mobile) Tone: professional, modern, and simulation‑focused — not arcade.

**Defining the Vision**

I'm now focusing on defining the vision. The core idea revolves around a React-based web application. It should be a deep-strategy simulation, a modern take on the classic NFL Head Coach, and is set to be "2026-ready." The emphasis is on analytics and a war-room style interface.


**Refining the UI/UX**

My focus has shifted to the UI/UX. The target audience is hardcore football strategy fans, similar to Football Manager players. I'm leaning toward a dark mode with neon accents, modular dashboards, and data-heavy visuals, but keeping it clean. The tech stack is defined as React 18, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Lucide React, and Recharts. I'm focusing on high-fidelity prototype elements for management and coaching loops, not a 3D game engine.


**Defining Core Components**

My current plan is to break the code into specific components. I'm starting with `index.tsx` as the React root and working my way through `App.tsx` for routing and layout. Types are defined in `types.ts`, and I'm creating mock data in `constants.ts`, including Teams, Players, and Plays. Next up are the components themselves, including Navigation, Dashboard, RosterView, GamePlan, MatchSim, and DraftRoom. My first coding step is setting up the types, including Player, Team, Play, and GameState, then the mock data with user and opponent teams, dummy players, and some plays.


**Developing App Structure**

I'm now diving into the core layout, starting with `App.tsx` and `Navigation.tsx`. I'm going with a sidebar, dark background, and standard nav links. Next, I'll tackle the `Dashboard.tsx`, focusing on high-contrast cards and key data points like opponent countdowns and team health, I'm thinking about a Win Probability preview. Roster Management (`RosterView.tsx`) will be a data table with player stats, and interactive views to show archetype. I'll implement charts for opponent tendencies in `GamePlan.tsx`.


**Simulating the Match**

I'm now in the "MatchSim.tsx" stage, aiming for a "Coach Mode" experience without stick skills. I've designed the layout as a scoreboard at the top, field view in the middle, play call sheet at the bottom, and real-time analytics on the side. The logic will be a simple state machine to manage the simulation and I plan to use "Next Gen Stats" style visuals.


**Implementing the Draft**

I've integrated a "Draft Player" button. I've standardized color schemes across backgrounds and cards, favoring a Slate palette with Cyan and Emerald accents. I also improved typography with uppercase headers and monospace numbers. I've added Win Probability to the Match screen, Cap Space and Owner Trust to the header, and Coach Glass terminology for immersion.


**Validating Libraries**

I'm now focusing on ensuring that `recharts` and `lucide-react` are integrated correctly. Also, I must validate all TypeScript types to minimize errors, especially during the data handling. I'm taking precautions for `Recharts`, by ensuring it will wrap in a responsive container. I also have to check the prompt to make sure it is "modern 2026-ready". The final polish involves glassmorphism, subtle borders, and crisp text.

entries.description: Root HTML with Tailwind and fonts
TypeScript definitions for the domain model

payload.text: Implement a contract negotiation system for players, including salary demands, contract length, and incentives. This should tie into the roster and team budget.

**Conceptualizing the Contract System**

I'm now diving into the core elements: salary, length, and incentives. These will obviously be pivotal in the contract system's design. The plan is to see how to best integrate these with the existing models, specifically in `types.ts`, and how that will influence the user interface. I'm leaning toward a new `ContractView.tsx`, too.


**Integrating Contract Details**

I'm now focused on the contract structure, beginning with updating `types.ts` to include `Contract` and `ContractDemand` interfaces, plus a `NegotiationStatus` enum. The `Player` interface will also be updated to hold contract information. I'm adding mock contract data within `constants.ts`, making sure at least one player has an expiring contract, reflecting active demands. Next up: building `ContractNegotiation.tsx` for contracts.


**Specifying Negotiation Logic**

I'm presently building the `ContractNegotiation` component. It'll have user input fields for contract offers (years, salary, signing bonus) and calculated fields like Total Value. There will be a Submit Offer button and acceptance/rejection logic. I'm focusing on user feedback based on offer proximity to player demands.

I'm updating `RosterView.tsx` to include state for player selection and a "Negotiate" button for expiring contracts. The `ContractNegotiation` will render when a player is selected.


**Developing the Negotiation Interface**

I'm expanding the player interface in `types.ts` to include optional contract demands, signaling negotiation availability. In `constants.ts`, I'm creating mock data, focusing on a specific player, L. Tunsil, with expiring contract demands. I'm updating `RosterView.tsx` to include a "Contract Status" column and a "Negotiate" button to open the new `ContractNegotiation` overlay when a player is selected, displaying all details.


**Defining Negotiation Parameters**

I'm now integrating the core contract negotiation controls. I'm focusing on "Player Interest", using a 0-100 scale, calculated offer and remaining team cap, as well as actions: "Make Offer" or "Withdraw".  The negotiation logic is a simple heuristic based on the ratio of offer value to demand value. I am building a `Contract` and `ContractDemand` interfaces and updating the `Player` interface, along with `MOCK_PLAYERS` in `constants.ts` to reflect a player's contract and demand status.


**Crafting a Modern UI**

I'm now focusing on a modern UI, starting with `ContractNegotiation.tsx`, prioritizing a dark mode and sleek inputs. I will incorporate a backdrop blur. It will have player info, agent remarks, and offer construction. Agent remarks will be styled to be a chat bubble. Sliders and bold numbers will build the offer. There will be a "Deal Probability" meter. Finally, `RosterView.tsx` gets `ContractNegotiation`. I want to use the state `selectedPlayerId`.


**Calculating Cap Impact**

I'm now integrating the budget check and player cost directly into the negotiation component. The prompt focuses on visually and logically tying the `14.2M` cap space into the flow. While ideally this would be global state, I'll treat it as a constant for this project, checking the mock budget locally within the `ContractNegotiation` component. I've updated `types.ts` with contract interfaces, `constants.ts` with data, and built out `ContractNegotiation.tsx` and updated `RosterView.tsx` with modal logic and the "Contract" column. I am deciding on whether to move cap space into the global nav.


**Implementing Offer Submission Logic**

I'm now zeroing in on offer submission within `ContractNegotiation.tsx`. I'm going to start with refining the logic within that view. It will need the `player` prop, `onClose` function, and `onSign` function, where `onSign` will update the player's contract within the parent state. The state management strategy will use local state within `RosterView`, minimizing file churn while I implement the feature. I am prioritizing demoing this feature.

To implement the contract negotiation system, I will introduce a new data model for contracts and demands, update the mock data to reflect a negotiation scenario (specifically for L. Tunsil), and create a sophisticated negotiation interface that integrates into the Roster View.

Here are the changes:

1.  **`types.ts`**: Added `Contract` and `ContractDemand` interfaces.
2.  **`constants.ts`**: Updated `MOCK_PLAYERS` with contract details. L. Tunsil is set as a pending free agent.
3.  **`components/ContractNegotiation.tsx`**: A new component featuring a "front-office" aesthetic for interactive negotiations, real-time agent feedback, and cap space calculations.
4.  **`components/RosterView.tsx`**: Updated to display contract status, handle the "Negotiate" action, and manage the negotiation modal.

entries.description: Added Contract and ContractDemand interfaces to the Player model
Updated mock players with contract data and added a negotiation scenario for Tunsil
New component for handling contract offers and agent interactions
Updated RosterView to include Contract columns and handle negotiation logic

payload.text: add a team selection input on the dashboard to switch each teram

**Defining Team Selection**

I'm currently focused on implementing team selection within the dashboard. The core idea is clear: I need to update the application's state to manage the selected team and integrate a UI element, likely a dropdown, into the `Dashboard.tsx` component. I'm exploring the implications for associated functionality.


**Integrating Team State**

I'm now diving deeper into the technical implementation. I've realized that the team selection logic needs to modify the app's state, specifically the data displayed in the `Dashboard.tsx` component. I'm leaning toward defining a `Team` interface for clarity. To meet the user request, I'll start by managing the selected team within the `Dashboard.tsx` component and then consider app-wide state implications for the Sidebar. I'm planning a dropdown in the dashboard header for team selection.


**Implementing Team Data**

I'm now focused on the initial data structure. I've decided to define a `TEAMS_DATA` constant, simulating a data source, directly in `Dashboard.tsx`. This will include essential team information like record, standings, and next opponent details. My plan is to make the dashboard reactive to team selection changes.


**Constructing the Team Select**

I've just added a select element into the dashboard header, which leverages the `TEAMS_DATA` object. This select element dynamically generates options based on the available teams. The component now responds to team selection changes. I'm focusing on the integration of the selected team ID to modify the data displayed within the dashboard. The goal is to use the `selectedTeamId` to reference the corresponding team data in the `TEAMS_DATA` object.


**Refining Dashboard Logic**

I'm now revising the `Dashboard.tsx` component based on the request. I'm adding a team selection input to switch between teams and highlighting the selected team in standings. I will include `ChevronDown` from `lucide-react` for styling. I've defined a `TEAMS` data structure and the initial state, `selectedTeam`, is 'HOU'. I'm also preparing for dynamic `standings` logic to highlight the selection.


**Updating Team Data Display**

I'm now revising my approach to the `teamStats` object within the dashboard. Instead of relying on a color tied directly to a team, I'm finding it makes more sense for each stat (OFF, DEF, ST) to have its own color independent of the team's primary color. My current focus is to refine the logic for displaying these stats in the dashboard, considering the user's specific request for adjustments within `components/Dashboard.tsx`. I'm using the `TEAMS_DB` mock data to populate this.


**Revising Team Display**

I've just added the new team data. Now, I'm working on dynamically displaying data for the team selected in the dashboard. I'm focusing on making sure that the data displayed in the components matches the selection. This includes making sure the record and next opponent details are correctly shown. I've also integrated the `setSelectedTeamId` function.


**Modifying Standings Logic**

I'm now refining the dashboard's standings section to be contextually relevant to the selected team.  I'll dynamically populate standings based on the current team's division. I'm also ensuring the team selection input is integrated within the "War Room" aesthetic. I'll focus on `<select>` element styling, potentially in the top right. I'll update the `Dashboard.tsx` file to handle these new changes.


**Styling Team Select**

I'm now styling the select element within the dashboard header. My goal is to integrate a styled `<select>` element in the header section, contributing to the dashboard's aesthetic. I will refine the styling to ensure a consistent look and feel with other elements within the application.


**Enhancing Data Structures**

I'm currently updating the `TEAMS_DATA` object to include more detailed standings information, which will be essential for contextually relevant display. I'm adding standings data, along with team stats and next opponent details for each team to improve the data displayed in the components. The mock data now has an improved structure.


**Finalizing Team Integration**

I'm now putting the finishing touches on the team integration. I've added comprehensive team data, including standings, stats, and next opponent information for each team. I'm focusing on ensuring all the components display the correct and relevant data based on the selected team.


**Implementing Week Updates**

I'm now focusing on integrating the week number. I can manage this with internal state within `Dashboard.tsx`, since `App.tsx` instantiates it without props. I'll be using `TEAMS_DB`, `useState` for `teamId`, and will insert a `<select>` element in the header. I will then update the JSX to use the `team` object. I need to make the select element responsive to changes.


**Adding Component Styling**

I'm now focusing on the dashboard's visual enhancements, especially the component styling. I'm leveraging the updated `TEAMS_DB` for data binding. I'll finalize the visual tweaks, ensuring the components are aligned with the overall design. I'm focusing on the record display.

To allow users to switch between teams on the dashboard, I will update `components/Dashboard.tsx`. I'll introduce a state-driven data model that swaps out team statistics, records, next opponents, and divisional standings when a different team is selected via a new dropdown menu.

entries.description: Added team selection dropdown and dynamic data rendering for multiple NFL teams

payload.text:
Allow the user to view all contracts

Simulate contract negotiations for players with expiring contracts, including salary demands and contract length.

Allow the user to accept or reject contract offers from players, with consequences for team morale and player acquisition.

**Building Contract Simulation**

I'm focusing on the implementation of a contract view feature, with a simulation engine. I'm leveraging the existing `ContractNegotiation` component and the `Roster` data structure to handle the expiring contracts. This will involve enhancements to those components to provide the user with the ability to simulate different negotiation scenarios.


**Developing Contract View**

I'm working on expanding the `RosterView` to show more contract details, not just salary and years remaining.
